Award.AwardTitle: Postdoctoral Research: Tissue Engineering and Sustainable Protein Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a post-doctoral study, during which the PI will be trained in ethnographic methods and will conduct an ethnographic study of laboratories in which in tissue engineers are working on developing a sustainable source of protein.

The topic is of general social importance because it pertains to biotechnology, animal welfare, and food security. The PI plans to produce academic journal articles, a book, and to share his results with the public through a workshop and museum exhibit. He has experience writing for a broad audience and this will contribute to the project having a broad impact.

ProgramReference.Text: SOC STUDIES OF SCI, ENG & TECH

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the two years of my NSF-funded postdoctoral research project, I accomplished several tasks I had identified as objectives in my original project proposal: First, I retrained in the anthropology and history of science by working with Stefan Helmreich of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, participating in seminars and workshops in MIT's History, Anthropology and Science and Technology Studies Program while also completing a reading list of books and articles equivalent to study for a PhD qualifying exam. I am now conversant with the general literature in these fields just as I am with the literature in my original field of doctoral study, intellectual history; I also have specialized knowledge in the history and anthropology of biotechnology. The mentorship of Helmreich and his colleagues at MIT was crucial, as I also retrained myself in the practice of ethographic fieldwork. By locating myself in an anthropology program, I learned much about the disciplinary norms of that field, and about how to frame social-scientific questions that target contemporary, rather than historical human practices.

Second, I completed extensive ethnographic fieldwork in the "cultured meat movement," spending time in the laboratories of tissue engineers who strive to create meat in laboratories as a protein source for a planet with a growing population and impending loss of farmland due to climate change. I also conducted fieldwork with activists on behalf of "cultured meat," with the venture capitalists whose money fuels this research, and with consultants and professional futurists who spend their time forecasting the potential futures of our food supply. I conducted and transcribed many interviews, took hundreds of pages of field notes, and began analyzing my experiences in the field as I began to plan journal articles and an eventual book on my topic. While some of my fieldwork was based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, I also conducted research in the San Francisco Bay Area (especially Palo Alto), London, Amsterdam and Maastricht, as well as in New York. 

Much of my ethnographic fieldwork dovetailed with my third stated objective in my project proposal, namely the "broader impacts" goal of contributing to public discussion of cultured meat technology, and of the potential impact of that technology both on our food system and on our relations with non-human animals; simply put, I became an expert speaker on cultured meat, invited to appear at multiple media events and interviewed by journalists even as I was interviewing researchers. I also served as an expert speaker for two nonprofits, the Palo Alto-based Institute for the Future, and the London-based Forum for the Future, benefitting in turn from their research into food futures. As I intended, I also wrote journalistic pieces on cultured meat, one of which, "The In Vitro Meat Cookbook," has been seen by some 12,000 readers on the Internet: https://medium.com/re-form/the-in-vitro-meat-cookbook-321aad71ce9a

As mentioned above, the ultimate goal of my research is a book on the effort to create cultured meat. As of September 1, 2015 I have written a book proposal and shared it with Stefan Helmreich and with an acquisitions editor at the University of California Press, who has an interest in granting an advance contract for the book; we are currently working together to rewrite the proposal, and I hope to have the book under contract by 2016. I am also about to submit my first journal article based on my research to Configurations, the journal of the Society for Literature, Science and the Arts. I have applied to the NSF for additional funding (via a STS Scholar's Award) to support additional ethnographic fieldwork as well as the further development of my book project.
